feed.title: Google Cloud: Cloud SQL for SQL Server
feed.subtitle: Changelog for Google Cloud product: Cloud SQL for SQL Server

entry.content:
You can now provision, manage and query your databases using the dedicated Gemini CLI extension for Cloud SQL for SQL Server. The extension provides full lifecycle control of your database—from provisioning instances, to exploring schemas and troubleshooting issues—from your command-line interface.

For more information, see Use Cloud SQL for SQL Server with MCP, Gemini CLI, and other agents.
entry.summary: Manage your Cloud SQL for SQL Server databases from the command line.
entry.title: Feature: Gemini CLI extension for Cloud SQL for SQL Server

entry.content: You can now retain point-in-time recovery (PITR) logs for an instance after its deletion for a specified retention period. These logs can be used to restore the deleted instance to a specific point in time. For more information, see Restore a deleted instance using PITR.
entry.summary: Point-in-time recovery logs for instances can now be retained for a specified period even after the instance is deleted. This allows for the restoration of deleted instances to a specific point in time.
entry.title: Feature: Point-in-Time Recovery Logs Retained After Deletion

entry.content:
You can have Cloud SQL create a Private Service Connect endpoint automatically. You can use this endpoint to access Cloud SQL instances through a VPC network. For more information, see Create a Private Service Connect endpoint automatically.

This feature is now generally available (GA).
entry.summary: Cloud SQL can now automatically create a Private Service Connect endpoint, allowing access to instances via a VPC network. This feature is now generally available.
entry.title: Feature: Private Service Connect endpoint for Cloud SQL

entry.content:
You can now enable your instance to take a final backup at instance deletion and define its retention period by setting the final backup instance setting.

You can also create a custom organization policy to define final backup instance settings. For more information, see Final backup.
entry.summary: You can now configure a final backup to be taken when an instance is deleted, along with its retention period, directly within the instance settings. This feature helps ensure data is preserved even after an instance is removed.
entry.title: Feature: Final backup on instance deletion

entry.content: Max degree of parallelism (MAXDOP) is a Microsoft database flag available for use in Cloud SQL for SQL Server. This flag lets you limit the maximum number of threads used when running a single query in a parallel plan.
entry.summary: The MAXDOP flag is now available for Cloud SQL for SQL Server. This flag allows you to control the maximum number of threads used for queries that run in parallel.
entry.title: Feature: MAXDOP flag in Cloud SQL for SQL Server

entry.content: You can save and manage SQL queries in Cloud SQL Studio. This feature is in Preview. For more information, see Saved queries overview.
entry.summary: Save and manage SQL queries in Cloud SQL Studio.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL Studio: Saved Queries

entry.content: Now you can use Private Service Connect backends, as an alternative to Private Service Connect endpoints, to access Cloud SQL instances.
entry.summary: Access Cloud SQL instances using Private Service Connect backends.
entry.title: Feature: Private Service Connect Backends for Cloud SQL

entry.content: Now you can create an IPv6 endpoint for Private Service Connect (PSC) connections. For more information, see Connect to an instance using Private Service Connect.
entry.summary: Create an IPv6 endpoint for Private Service Connect connections.
entry.title: Feature: IPv6 PSC Endpoint

entry.content: You can no longer set a deny maintenance period for instances that are running a maintenance version older than 12 months. To update your instance, perform self-service maintenance or wait until the next maintenance window to update your instance automatically. For more information about maintenance, see Maintenance updates on Cloud SQL instances.
entry.summary: Instances running an old maintenance version can no longer have a deny maintenance period set. Update your instance via self-service maintenance or wait for the next automatic maintenance window.
entry.title: Deprecated: Maintenance Update for Cloud SQL Instances

entry.content: Cloud SQL now supports Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity. With PSC outbound connectivity, you can attach a PSC interface to your existing Cloud SQL PSC-enabled instances to allow your instances to make outbound connections to your network. For more information, see PSC outbound connections.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL now supports Private Service Connect (PSC) outbound connectivity, enabling instances to connect to your network.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL PSC Outbound Connectivity

entry.content:
Cloud SQL now offers planned maintenance and machine tier upgrades for your Cloud SQL Enterprise plus instances with near-zero downtime for eligible instances.

For more information, see Maintenance updates on Cloud SQL instances.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL now offers planned maintenance and machine tier upgrades for your Cloud SQL Enterprise plus instances with near-zero downtime for eligible instances.
entry.title: Feature: Cloud SQL planned maintenance and upgrades

entry.content:
Cloud SQL now offers two options of backup services to manage your instance's backups:

  • Enhanced backups (Preview): backups are managed and stored in a centralized backup management project that leverages the Backup and DR service, and provides enforced retention, granular scheduling, and longer retention.
  • Standard backups (existing option): backups are created, managed, and stored in the same project as your Cloud SQL instances.

You can choose between these options based on your instance's requirements and needs. Although instances can't use both backup options at the same time, Cloud SQL gives you the ability to switch between these backup options as necessary.

For more information about the available options and their limitations, see Backup options.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL introduces enhanced backups with centralized management, enforced retention, granular scheduling, and longer retention, leveraging the Backup and DR service. Standard backups remain an option, managed within the same project. You can switch between these options based on your needs.
entry.title: Feature: New Backup Options for Cloud SQL

entry.content: Cloud SQL for SQL Server now offers Active Directory support for write endpoints. For more information, see Write endpoints across forests.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL for SQL Server now supports Active Directory for write endpoints, allowing for cross-forest trusts.
entry.title: Feature: Active Directory Support for Cloud SQL for SQL Server

entry.content:
Cloud SQL for SQL Server now offers the maximum server memory recommender.

Database instances running with an allocation of memory that's either too low or too high might experience performance issues.

The max server memory (mb) flag limits the amount of memory that Cloud SQL can allocate for its internal pools. You can manually set a value for this flag, or omit the flag and let Cloud SQL manage memory limits for you automatically.

For more information, see Optimize maximum server memory usage.
entry.summary: Cloud SQL for SQL Server now includes a feature that recommends the optimal server memory allocation. This helps prevent performance issues caused by insufficient or excessive memory, allowing you to either manually set the 'max server memory (mb)' flag or let Cloud SQL manage it automatically.
entry.title: Feature: New memory recommender for Cloud SQL for SQL Server
